articles.headline: Madrid Leans on Its Troubled Banks to Buy Its Bonds
articles.snippet: Economists warn that over the long term, Spain will have trouble meeting its substantial financial requirements until foreign investors inject new money.
articles.abstract: Economists warn that over the long term, Spain will have trouble meeting its substantial financial requirements until foreign investors inject new money.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — While the Spanish government was able to sell all the bonds it wanted to on Thursday, it mostly sold to the usual buyers: Spain’s increasingly fragile banks.

articles.headline: Accounting Backfired at MF Global
articles.snippet: Trustees trying to unravel what happened at MF Global have focused on one technique, allowed under current accounting rules, that allowed the firm to buy bonds and book immediate profits.
articles.abstract: Trustees trying to unravel what happened at MF Global have focused on one technique, allowed under current accounting rules, that allowed the firm to buy bonds and book immediate profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back when I was studying accounting at Columbia University’s business school, the professor had a handy way to determine whether it made sense for a company to recognize revenue: Had it completed the hard task in its business?

articles.headline: Approval Rating for Justices Hits Just 44% in New Poll
articles.snippet: Three-quarters of Americans say the Supreme Court’s decisions are sometimes influenced by personal or political views, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: Three-quarters of Americans say the Supreme Court’s decisions are sometimes influenced by personal or political views, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just 44 percent of Americans approve of the job the Supreme Court is doing and three-quarters say the justices’ decisions are sometimes influenced by their personal or political views, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times and CBS News.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Allison Kopicki

articles.headline: Once-Reticent Investors Join Shareholder Revolts
articles.snippet: Proxy season is traditionally dominated by well-known activist investors, but this year has been different with mutual funds and other institutional investors applying more pressure to corporate boards.
articles.abstract: Proxy season is traditionally dominated by well-known activist investors, but this year has been different with mutual funds and other institutional investors applying more pressure to corporate boards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every spring, corporate chieftains and their boards squash uprisings from a familiar batch of pugnacious investors, a ritual that shields many companies from major change.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Katherine Reynolds Lewis

articles.headline: As Grain Piles Up, India’s Poor Still Go Hungry
articles.snippet: Despite surplus grain stockpiles, malnourishment is widespread in India, where politicians are facing pressure to deal with corruption and waste in distribution programs.
articles.abstract: Despite surplus grain stockpiles, malnourishment is widespread in India, where politicians are facing pressure to deal with corruption and waste in distribution programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: RANWAN, India — In this north Indian village, workers recently dismantled stacks of burned and mildewed rice while flies swarmed nearby over spoiled wheat. Local residents said the rice crop had been sitting along the side of a highway for several years and was now being sent to a distillery to be turned into liquor.

articles.headline: Campaigns Blitz 9 Swing States in a Battle of Ads
articles.snippet: The presidential campaigns and their allies have been bombarding a shrinking pool of swing voters with the earliest concentration of advertisements in the modern political era.
articles.abstract: The presidential campaigns and their allies have been bombarding a shrinking pool of swing voters with the earliest concentration of advertisements in the modern political era.
articles.lead_paragraph: HENDERSON, Nev. — The presidential campaigns and their allies are zeroing in mainly on nine swing states, bombarding them with commercials in the earliest concentration of advertising in modern politics.

articles.headline: U.N. Monitors in Syria Find Grisly Traces of Massacre
articles.snippet: Confronting blood, body parts and shelled buildings, a United Nations team quietly collected evidence on Friday of a mass atrocity in a desolate hamlet.
articles.abstract: Confronting blood, body parts and shelled buildings, a United Nations team quietly collected evidence on Friday of a mass atrocity in a desolate hamlet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Confronting a scene of congealed blood, scattered body parts, shelled buildings, bullet holes and the smell of burned flesh, United Nations monitors in Syria quietly collected evidence on Friday of a mass atrocity in a desolate hamlet, more than 24 hours after Syrian forces and government supporters blocked their first attempt to visit the site.

articles.headline: Trustee Sees Customers Trampled at MF Global
articles.snippet: A report on the collapse of MF Global reveals a questionable series of moves that indicate the firm failed in its duty to protect the assets of its clients.
articles.abstract: A report on the collapse of MF Global reveals a questionable series of moves that indicate the firm failed in its duty to protect the assets of its clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the collapse of the commodities brokerage firm MF Global were a murder mystery, the revelation that $1.6 billion of customer money had disappeared would be the equivalent of finding the corpse.

articles.headline: Hosts of ‘Car Talk’ to Retire After 35 Years of Automotive Banter
articles.snippet: The brothers Tom Magliozzi and Ray Magliozzi, whose show has been a staple of NPR for decades, will stop producing new shows this fall.
articles.abstract: The brothers Tom Magliozzi and Ray Magliozzi, whose show has been a staple of NPR for decades, will stop producing new shows this fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: 6:23 p.m. | Updated For years now, after their broadcasts, Tom and Ray Magliozzi, the hosts of the public-radio hit “Car Talk,” have been ranking the listener calls they receive on a scale from five to one, with five being the most entertaining.
